title: Forces: Frictional Force, Gravitational Force, Elastic Spring Force
subject: Science

questions.question: Which of the following BEST defines a force?
questions.explanation: A force is defined as a push or a pull. It can cause objects to move, stop, change speed, change direction, or change shape.

questions.question: A boy kicks a stationary football. Which effect of a force is shown?
options: A force can change the shape of an object
A force can stop a moving object
A force can increase the mass of an object
A force can move a stationary object
questions.explanation: The football was stationary before the kick. The force of the kick moves it, demonstrating that a force can move a stationary object.

questions.question: A cyclist applies brakes to slow down. Which effect of a force is demonstrated?
options: A force can change the direction of motion
A force can move a stationary object
A force can slow down a moving object
A force can change the shape of an object
questions.explanation: The braking force acts opposite to the bicycle's motion, causing it to slow down. This shows that a force can slow down a moving object.

questions.question: Which type of force acts when you stretch a rubber band?
questions.explanation: When you stretch a rubber band, you are applying a force that stretches it. The rubber band exerts an elastic spring force trying to return to its original shape.

questions.question: What causes objects to have weight?
options: The amount of material in the object
Gravitational force acting on the object
questions.explanation: Weight is caused by gravitational force pulling objects toward the center of the Earth. The greater the gravitational force acting on an object, the greater its weight.

questions.question: A book slides across a table and gradually stops. Which force is responsible for stopping it?
questions.explanation: Frictional force acts between the book and the table surface, opposing the motion and eventually causing the book to stop.

questions.question: When you compress a spring and then release it, what happens?
options: The frictional force keeps it compressed
The gravitational force pulls it downward
The elastic spring force pushes it back to its original shape
questions.explanation: When compressed, a spring stores elastic potential energy. When released, the elastic spring force acts to return the spring to its original shape.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT an effect of a force?
options: A force can change the direction of motion
A force can change the shape of an object
A force can speed up a moving object
A force can change the color of an object
questions.explanation: A force cannot change the color of an object. Forces can: move stationary objects, change speed/direction of moving objects, stop moving objects, and change shapes of objects.

questions.question: What would happen to your weight if you went to the Moon?
options: Your weight would increase because gravitational force is stronger
Your weight would stay the same
You would have no weight on the Moon
Your weight would decrease because gravitational force is weaker
questions.explanation: Weight depends on gravitational force. The Moon's gravity is about 1/6 of Earth's, so your weight would be about 1/6 of what it is on Earth.

questions.question: Why do car tires have patterns (treads) on them?
options: To decrease friction for faster movement
To make the tires look attractive
To reduce the weight of the tires
To increase friction for better grip on the road
questions.explanation: Tire treads increase the surface area and create channels to improve friction between the tires and the road, providing better grip and safety.

questions.question: A ball is thrown upward into the air. What force causes it to eventually fall back down?
questions.explanation: Gravitational force constantly pulls the ball downward toward Earth. Even when thrown upward, gravity eventually overcomes the upward motion and pulls it back down.

questions.question: Which surface would have the LEAST frictional force for sliding a heavy box?
questions.explanation: Ice is smooth and slippery, creating very little friction. This makes it difficult to walk on ice but easy to slide objects across it.

questions.question: When you pull a door open, what kind of force are you applying?
questions.explanation: Pulling the door toward you is applying a pulling force. Forces are categorized as either pushes or pulls.

questions.question: What happens to the elastic spring force when you stretch a spring further?
options: The elastic spring force stays the same
questions.explanation: The more you stretch (or compress) a spring, the greater the elastic spring force it exerts trying to return to its original length.

questions.question: Why is it harder to pedal a bicycle on a sandy path compared to a paved road?
options: Gravitational force is stronger on sand
The bicycle has more elastic spring force on sand
Sand reduces the weight of the bicycle
There is more frictional force on sand
questions.explanation: Sand creates more friction than a smooth paved surface. The wheels sink into sand, increasing frictional force and making it harder to pedal.

questions.question: Which object experiences gravitational force?
questions.explanation: All objects on Earth experience gravitational force pulling them toward the Earth's center. This gives all objects weight, regardless of their size or material.

questions.question: What should you do to reduce friction between moving parts in a machine?
questions.explanation: Lubricants like oil create a smooth layer between surfaces, reducing friction. This helps machines work more smoothly and efficiently.

questions.question: A spring is stretched and then released. What energy conversion occurs?
questions.explanation: When stretched, a spring stores elastic potential energy. When released, this converts to kinetic energy as the spring moves back to its original position.

questions.question: Which statement about forces is scientifically accurate?
options: Forces can only act on living things
Forces always make objects move faster
Forces are a type of energy
questions.explanation: Forces always occur in pairs - for every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force (though this concept is typically introduced at higher levels).

questions.question: A student claims: 'Friction is always a bad thing.' How would you respond using scientific knowledge?
options: The student is correct - friction should always be reduced
Friction is only useful in sports, not in daily life
Friction is only important for heavy objects
Friction can be useful - it helps us walk without slipping and cars stop safely
questions.explanation: Friction has both advantages and disadvantages. Useful friction helps us walk, write with pencils, and vehicles brake safely. Unwanted friction causes wear and wastes energy in machines.
